description: The available commands for execution are listed below.

global_flags.description: Switch to a different working directory before executing the given subcommand.
Show this help output or the help for a specified subcommand.

subcommands.name: apply
subcommands.description: Create or update infrastructure

flags.description: Skip interactive approval of plan before applying.
Path to backup the existing state file before modifying. Defaults to the "-state-out" path with ".backup" extension. Set to "-" to disable backup.
If Terraform produces any warnings that are not accompanied by errors, show them in a more compact form that includes only the summary messages.
Destroy Terraform-managed infrastructure. The command "terraform destroy" is a convenience alias for this option.
Ask for input for variables if not directly set.
Don't hold a state lock during the operation. This is dangerous if others might concurrently run commands against the same workspace.
Duration to retry a state lock.
If specified, output won't contain any color.
Limit the number of parallel resource operations. Defaults to 10.
Terraform will plan to replace this resource instance instead of doing an update or no-op action.
Path to read and save state (unless state-out is specified). Defaults to "terraform.tfstate". Legacy option for the local backend only. See the local backend's documentation for more information.

Path to write state to that is different than "-state". This can be used to preserve the old state. Legacy option for the local backend only. See the local backend's documentation for more information.
Set a value for one of the input variables in the root module of the configuration. Use this option more than once to set more than one variable.
Load variable values from the given file, in addition to the default files terraform.tfvars and *.auto.tfvars. Use this option more than once to include more than one variables file.

subcommands.name: console
subcommands.description: Try Terraform expressions at an interactive command prompt

flags.description: Create a new plan (as if running "terraform plan") and then evaluate expressions against its planned state, instead of evaluating against the current state. You can use this to inspect the effects of configuration changes that haven't been applied yet.
Legacy option for the local backend only. See the local backend's documentation for more information.
Set a variable in the Terraform configuration. This flag can be set multiple times.
Set variables in the Terraform configuration from a file. If "terraform.tfvars" or any ".auto.tfvars" files are present, they will be automatically loaded.

subcommands.name: destroy
subcommands.description: Destroy previously-created infrastructure

subcommands.name: fmt
subcommands.description: Reformat your configuration in the standard style

flags.description: Check if the input is formatted. Exit status will be 0 if all input is properly formatted and non-zero otherwise.
Display diffs of formatting changes
Don't list files whose formatting differs (always disabled if using STDIN)
If specified, output won't contain any color.
Also process files in subdirectories. By default, only the given directory (or current directory) is processed.
Don't write to source files (always disabled if using STDIN or -check)

subcommands.name: force-unlock
subcommands.description: Release a stuck lock on the current workspace

flags.description: Don't ask for input for unlock confirmation.

subcommands.name: get
subcommands.description: Install or upgrade remote Terraform modules

flags.description: Disable text coloring in the output.
Set the Terraform test directory, defaults to "tests".
Check already-downloaded modules for available updates and install the newest versions available.

subcommands.name: graph
subcommands.description: Generate a Graphviz graph of the steps in an operation

flags.description: Highlight any cycles in the graph with colored edges. This helps when diagnosing cycle errors. This option is supported only when illustrating a real evaluation graph, selected using the -type=TYPE option.
(deprecated) In prior versions of Terraform, specified the depth of modules to show in the output.
Render graph using the specified plan file instead of the configuration in the current directory. Implies -type=apply.

Type of operation graph to output. Can be: plan, plan-refresh-only, plan-destroy, or apply. By default Terraform just summarizes the relationships between the resources in your configuration, without any particular operation in mind. Full operation graphs are more detailed but therefore often harder to read.

subcommands.name: import
subcommands.description: Associate existing infrastructure with a Terraform resource

flags.description: Path to a directory of Terraform configuration files to use to configure the provider. Defaults to pwd. If no config files are present, they must be provided via the input prompts or env vars.
A rare option used for the remote backend only. See the remote backend documentation for more information.
Disable interactive input prompts.
Don't hold a state lock during the operation. This is dangerous if others might concurrently run commands against the same workspace.
Duration to retry a state lock.
If specified, output won't contain any color.
Set a variable in the Terraform configuration. This flag can be set multiple times. This is only useful with the "-config" flag.
Set variables in the Terraform configuration from a file. If "terraform.tfvars" or any ".auto.tfvars" files are present, they will be automatically loaded.

subcommands.name: init
subcommands.description: Prepare your working directory for other commands

flags.description: Disable backend or HCP Terraform initialization for this configuration and use what was previously initialized instead.

Configuration to be merged with what is in the configuration file's 'backend' block. This can be either a path to an HCL file with key/value assignments (same format as terraform.tfvars) or a 'key=value' format, and can be specified multiple times. The backend type must be in the configuration itself.
Suppress prompts about copying state data when initializing a new state backend. This is equivalent to providing a "yes" to all confirmation prompts.
Copy the contents of the given module into the target directory before initialization.
Disable downloading modules for this configuration.

A rare option used for HCP Terraform and the remote backend only. Set this to ignore checking that the local and remote Terraform versions use compatible state representations, making an operation proceed even when there is a potential mismatch. See the documentation on configuring Terraform with HCP Terraform or Terraform Enterprise for more information.
Disable interactive prompts. Note that some actions may require interactive prompts and will error if input is disabled.
If specified, machine readable output will be printed in JSON format.
Don't hold a state lock during backend migration. This is dangerous if others might concurrently run commands against the same workspace.
Duration to retry a state lock.
Set a dependency lockfile mode. Currently only "readonly" is valid.
Reconfigure a backend, and attempt to migrate any existing state.
If specified, output won't contain any color.
Directory containing plugin binaries. This overrides all default search paths for plugins, and prevents the automatic installation of plugins. This flag can be used multiple times.
Reconfigure a backend, ignoring any saved configuration.
Set the Terraform test directory, defaults to "tests".
Install the latest module and provider versions allowed within configured constraints, overriding the default behavior of selecting exactly the version recorded in the dependency lockfile.

subcommands.name: login
subcommands.description: Obtain and save credentials for a remote host

subcommands.name: logout
subcommands.description: Remove locally-stored credentials for a remote host

subcommands.name: metadata
subcommands.description: Metadata related commands

subcommands.name: functions
subcommands.description: Show signatures and descriptions for the available functions

subcommands.name: modules
subcommands.description: Show all declared modules in a working directory

flags.description: If specified, output declared Terraform modules and their resolved versions in a machine-readable format.

subcommands.name: output
subcommands.description: Show output values from your root module

flags.description: If specified, machine readable output will be printed in JSON format.
If specified, output won't contain any color.
For value types that can be automatically converted to a string, will print the raw string directly, rather than a human-oriented representation of the value.
Path to the state file to read. Defaults to "terraform.tfstate". Legacy option for the local backend only. See the local backend's documentation for more information.

subcommands.name: plan
subcommands.description: Show changes required by the current configuration

flags.description: If Terraform produces any warnings that are not accompanied by errors, shows them in a more compact form that includes only the summary messages.
Select the "destroy" planning mode, which creates a plan to destroy all objects currently managed by this Terraform configuration instead of the usual behavior.
Return detailed exit codes when the command exits.

(Experimental) If import blocks are present in configuration, instructs Terraform to generate HCL for any imported resources not already present. The configuration is written to a new file at PATH, which must not already exist. Terraform may still attempt to write configuration if the plan errors.
Ask for input for variables if not directly set.
Don't hold a state lock during the operation. This is dangerous if others might concurrently run commands against the same workspace.
Duration to retry a state lock.
If specified, output won't contain any color.
Write a plan file to the given path. This can be used as input to the "apply" command.
Limit the number of concurrent operations. Defaults to 10.

Skip checking for external changes to remote objects while creating the plan. This can potentially make planning faster, but at the expense of possibly planning against a stale record of the remote system state.

Select the "refresh only" planning mode, which checks whether remote objects still match the outcome of the most recent Terraform apply but does not propose any actions to undo any changes made outside of Terraform.

Force replacement of a particular resource instance using its resource address. If the plan would've normally produced an update or no-op action for this instance, Terraform will plan to replace it instead. You can use this option multiple times to replace more than one object.
A legacy option used for the local backend only. See the local backend's documentation for more information.

Limit the planning operation to only the given module, resource, or resource instance and all of its dependencies. You can use this option multiple times to include more than one object. This is for exceptional use only.
Set a value for one of the input variables in the root module of the configuration. Use this option more than once to set more than one variable.
Load variable values from the given file, in addition to the default files terraform.tfvars and *.auto.tfvars. Use this option more than once to include more than one variables file.

subcommands.name: providers
subcommands.description: Show the providers required for this configuration

flags.description: Set the Terraform test directory, defaults to "tests".

subcommands.name: lock
subcommands.description: Write out dependency locks for the configured providers

flags.description: Enable the usage of the globally configured plugin cache. This will speed up the locking process, but the providers won't be loaded from an authoritative source.
Consult the given filesystem mirror directory instead of the origin registry for each of the given providers.
Consult the given network mirror (given as a base URL) instead of the origin registry for each of the given providers.
Choose a target platform to request package checksums for.
Set the Terraform test directory, defaults to "tests".

subcommands.name: mirror
subcommands.description: Save local copies of all required provider plugins

flags.description: Ignore the provider lock file when fetching providers. By default the mirror command will use the version info in the lock file if the configuration directory has been previously initialized.

Choose which target platform to build a mirror for. By default Terraform will obtain plugin packages suitable for the platform where you run this command. Use this flag multiple times to include packages for multiple target systems.

subcommands.name: schema
subcommands.description: Show schemas for the providers used in the configuration

subcommands.name: query
subcommands.description: Search and list remote infrastructure with Terraform

flags.description: Instructs Terraform to generate import and resource blocks for any found results. The configuration is written to a new file at PATH, which must not already exist. When this option is used with the json option, the generated configuration will be part of the JSON output instead of written to a file.
If specified, machine readable output will be printed in JSON format
If specified, output won't contain any color.
Set a value for one of the input variables in the query file of the configuration. Use this option more than once to set more than one variable.
Load variable values from the given file, in addition to the default files terraform.tfvars and *.auto.tfvars. Use this option more than once to include more than one variables file.

subcommands.name: refresh
subcommands.description: Update the state to match remote systems

flags.description: If Terraform produces any warnings that are not accompanied by errors, show them in a more compact form that includes only the summary messages.
Ask for input for variables if not directly set.
Don't hold a state lock during the operation. This is dangerous if others might concurrently run commands against the same workspace.
Duration to retry a state lock.
If specified, output won't contain any color.
Limit the number of concurrent operations. Defaults to 10.
Resource to target. Operation will be limited to this resource and its dependencies. This flag can be used multiple times.
Set a variable in the Terraform configuration. This flag can be set multiple times.
Set variables in the Terraform configuration from a file. If "terraform.tfvars" or any ".auto.tfvars" files are present, they will be automatically loaded.

subcommands.name: show
subcommands.description: Show the current state or a saved plan

flags.description: If specified, output the Terraform plan or state in a machine-readable form.
If specified, output won't contain any color.

subcommands.name: stacks
subcommands.description: Manage HCP Terraform stack operations

flags.description: Switch to a different working directory before executing the given subcommand.
Disable color output. Must be explicitly set to true or false.
Override the default directory where the stack plugin binary is cached.
An alias for the "version" subcommand.
Show this usage output or the usage for a specified subcommand. Use after the command: terraform stacks <command> -usage

flags.description: Overwrite the current directory as the target for the root configuration.

flags.description: Overwrite the current directory as the target for the root configuration.
Output results in JSON format.
Disable color output. Must be explicitly set to true or false.

The name of the project to target. Overrides the ENV VAR 'TF_STACKS_PROJECT_NAME' if provided.
The ID of the stack to fetch for. Has precedence over the -stack-name.
The name of the stack to target. Overrides the ENV VAR 'TF_STACKS_STACK_NAME' if provided.

subcommands.name: test
subcommands.description: Execute integration tests for Terraform modules

flags.description: If specified, Terraform will execute this test run remotely using HCP Terraform or Terraform Enterprise. You must specify the source of a module registered in a private module registry as the argument to this flag. This allows Terraform to associate the cloud run with the correct HCP Terraform or Terraform Enterprise module and organization.
If specified, Terraform will only execute the test files specified by this flag. You can use this option multiple times to execute more than one test file.
If specified, machine readable output will be printed in JSON format
Saves a test report in JUnit XML format to the specified file. This is currently incompatible with remote test execution using the the -cloud-run option. The file path must be relative or absolute.
If specified, output won't contain any color.
Limit the number of concurrent operations within the plan/apply operation of a test run. Defaults to 10.
Set the Terraform test directory, defaults to "tests".

Load variable values from the given file, in addition to the default files terraform.tfvars and *.auto.tfvars. Use this option more than once to include more than one variables file.
Print the plan or state for each test run block as it executes.

subcommands.name: validate
subcommands.description: Check whether the configuration is valid

flags.description: Produce output in a machine-readable JSON format, suitable for use in text editor integrations and other automated systems. Always disables color.
If specified, output won't contain any color.
If specified, Terraform will not validate test files.
If specified, the command will also validate .tfquery.hcl files.
Set the Terraform test directory, defaults to "tests".

subcommands.name: version
subcommands.description: Show the current Terraform version

subcommands.name: workspace
subcommands.description: Workspace management

subcommands.name: list
subcommands.description: List Workspaces

subcommands.name: new
subcommands.description: Create a new workspace

flags.description: Don't hold a state lock during the operation. This is dangerous if others might concurrently run commands against the same workspace.
Duration to retry a state lock.
Copy an existing state file into the new workspace.

subcommands.name: select
subcommands.description: Select a workspace

flags.description: Create the Terraform workspace if it doesn't exist.

subcommands.name: show
subcommands.description: Show the name of the current workspace
